div.head: Bayesian Reconstruction of Functional Images
div.p: Using Anatomical Information as Priors Gene Gindi, Mindy Lee, Anand Rangarajan, and I. George Zubal Absh-act-We propose a Bayesian method whereby maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimates of functional (PET and SPECT) images may be reconstructed with the aid of prior information derived from registered anatomical MR images of the same slice. Our prior information consists of significant anatomical boundaries that are likely to correspond to discontinuities in an otherwise spatially smooth radionuclide distribution. Our algorithm, like others proposed recently, seeks smooth solutions with occasional discontinuities; the contribution here is the inclusion of a coupling term that influences the creation of discontinuities in the vicinity of the significant anatomical boundaries. Simulations on anatomically derived mathematical phantoms are presented. Although computationally intense in its current implication, the reconstructions are improved (ROI-RMS error) relative to filtered backprojection and EM-ML reconstructions. The simulations show that the inclusion of position-dependent anatomical prior information leads to further improvement relative to Bayesian reconstructions without the anatomical prior. The algorithm exhibits a certain degree of robustness with respect to errors in the location of anatomical boundaries.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION N BOTH positron emission tomography (PET) and single
div.p: I photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging, there is a significant information loss in going from object to projection data through the projection imaging process. In an attempt to improve reconstructions, probabilistic frameworks incorporating object priors have been proposed by several workers [1]- [8]. In most of these previous works, the model for the object priors was motivated by assumptions of object smoothness with occasional discontinuities. These smoothness assumptions are generic in that they apply to the general class of objects under consideration. One might well suppose that prior information concerning the smoothness and discontinuities of the speciJic object being imaged should provide some additional advantage relative to generic information.

An opportunity to obtain such prior information is provided by recent results in the registration of anatomical (computerized tomography-CT or magnetic resonance imaging-MRI) images with functional (SPECT or PET) images from the same patient [9], [lo]. More recently, these registration techniques have been applied to brain SPECT perfusion images for registration with MRI anatomy [ll],

[12]. To the extent that boundaries of some anatomical objects correspond to edges in the spatial distribution of radiopharmaceuticals, we indeed get just the sort of nongeneric smoothness information mentioned above. Previous work incorporating anatomical priors has been reported in [ 131- [15].

In this paper, we first comment in Section I1 on the use of anatomical images as priors, then offer a Bayesian reconstruction model in Section 111. Results on simulated SPECT reconstructions utilizing a mathematical phantom derived from an MRI brain image are presented in Section IV. Our conclusions are presented in Section V.

div.head: THE ANATOMICAL IMAGE A S PRIOR
div.p: The utility of anatomical priors depends on the degree of spatial correlation of anatomical structure with radionuclide distribution. In the cases where the correlation is good, we may expect the anatomy to serve as a useful prior. Below, we give one example of good correlation obtained from a study' (unrelated to the present work) involving neuroreceptor seeking radiopharmaceuticals. Figure 1 shows an autoradiograph, obtained from thin physical slices of a monkey brain, after injection of a neuroreceptor-seeking pharmaceutical. The autoradiograph, with a spatial resolution of less than 1 mm, shows the receptor density distribution immediately after sacrificing the animal. The correlation to anatomy is striking. The boundary between white and gray matter is distinct, the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN-round structure in the center) is clearly demonstrated as is the striatum (structure above the LGN). Furthermore, the distribution within certain regions, such as white and gray matter, is reasonably uniform. Since these and other regions can be delineated on anatomical images, there is some hope that selected boundaries obtained from CT or MRI can indeed serve as priors in a reconstruction.

div.p: This is the energy function which is used in our simulations. The energy function highlights two aspects of our approach. The first is the use of an intermodality term that modulates the creation of discontinuities according to anatomical as well as functional information. The second is the use of a cusp-like potential which alleviates the problems of non-convexity and hot spots.

So far, we have not mentioned an actual algorithm that minimizes (21). The cusp-like potential used here is not differentiable and, hence, gradient-based minimization methods are ruled out. Instead we use a quenching algorithm which is identical to the zero temperature limit of simulated annealing. The details are presented in the next section. We note here that the concern in the paper is in the incremental improvement in reconstruction due to the intermodality prior and we are not concerned at present with issues of efficiency in the minimization algorithm. Nevertheless, in Section IV, we report some relative execution times of this quenching algorithm relative to an EM-ML update algorithm.

We note that it is common in image processing and computer vision problems to include line process clique potentials to enforce higher level constraints that encourage discontinuities to occur along smooth, unbroken contours. Furthermore, the clique potentials discourage the formation of discontinuities along parallel, closely-spaced contours ("thick" contours). In particular, a previous effort [ 131, in anatomical-functional correlation have made use of clique potentials. Our results, however, show that the anatomical edge information e serves the above purposes.

In our formulation, the formation of smooth, unbroken contours is encouraged by the anatomical information e through the lowering of the penalty for creating a discontinuity. High values of e occur on a band of smooth contours and discontinuities tend to follow the locus of e. However, the intrinsic properties of the weak membrane promote the formation of smooth, thin contours (see for example, in [17] on pages 87-88) rather than on a bund of contours. These intrinisic properties, "hysteresis" (formation of smooth contours) and "non-maximum suppression" (formation of thin contours), are discussed extensively in [17].

Note also that in the absence of cliques, the line processes are independent and can thus be eliminated resulting in an equivalent energy function that depends only on the source intensities. This simplifies the search since we do not have to minimize the energy function with respect to the line processes.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: The optimization was carried out via a quenching procedure. In our implementation, individual pixels are visited sequentially following a raster scan. One iteration corresponds to a single raster scan. At each pixel, the source intensity is altered and the change in energy is calculated. A move that reduces energy is always accepted, and a move that increases energy is always rejected. Pixels are altered according to the following scheme: a new value is sampled from a Gaussian probability density whose mean is equal to the current pixel intensity and whose standard deviation is fixed at 55. This analog value is added to the current pixel intensity and the result discretized to the nearest integer. The parameter space for F is thus discretized to 256 levels. Note that the allowed intensity range varies from 0 to 255, and when a sampled pixel value falls out of this range, we use a wraparound scheme wherein 255 is added to values less than 0 and subtracted from values greater than 255. The algorithm is run until the number of pixels whose values change in an iteration reaches a plateau of less than a suitably chosen threshold. By plateau we mean that the number of pixel changes per iteration is less than or equal to the threshold for 100 consecutive iterations.

Following [ 11, we form an initial estimate using the conventional expectation-maximization, maximum-likelihood (EM-ML) algorithm. In general, the EM-ML estimate is expected to get us close to the answer, thus saving an excessive number of iterations.

The first set of results is shown in Fig. 3. Figure 3(a) shows a 64 x 64 brain phantom that was obtained from hand tracing selected anatomical edges of an actual MRI image of a human brain. The phantom has three regions that represent gray matter, white matter, and a generalized internal structure. The outer region (gray matter) was completely and homogeneously filled with an equivalent radioisotope density of concentration 100; the intermediate region (white matter) was similarly filled with values of 25; and the two inner regions with values of 50. These regions crudely approximate the expected radioisotope density of a brain perfusion agent. Projection data was mathematically generated by calculating the Radon transform using 64 equiangular projections around 360 degrees with 64 detector bins per projection. Independent Poisson noise was added to each detector bin. The total counts were 3322400.

Figure 3(b) shows the result obtained using filtered backprojection (FI3P) with a ramp filter with no lowpass cutoff. Figure 3(c) shows the result obtained useing EM-ML after 90 iterations where the total RMS error was least.

This is essentially an implementation of our reconstruction algorithm without benifit of the anatomical information and is obtained simply by setting e ( i , j ) = 0 everywhere in our energy function (21). A value of tcl = 13.0 and X = 0.69 was used. The energy function no longer depends on K Z once e ( i , j ) is set to zero. The initial estimate was obtained with 25 iterations of the EM-ML algorithm. The weak membrane reconstruction is obtained using our quenching algorithm after 369 iterations. The plateau threshold for the quenching algorithm was 14.

The next result, Fig. 3(e), demonstrates the improvement in the reconstruction due to the anatomical information. Here, we used our energy function (21) with tc1 = 15.0 and tc2 = 5.0, and X = 0.69. The anatomical information, illustrated in Fig. 3(g), displays the combined vertical and horizontal edge maps. The value of e ( i , j ) is set to unity along the depicted boundaries and is zero elsewhere. Again, the initial estimate was obtained with 25 iterations of the EM-ML algorithm and the same plateau was used for the quenching algorithm, resulting in a total of 400 iterations.

In order to be useful, the reconstruction algorithm should be robust with respect to uncertainties in the correlation between function and anatomy. The uncertainty can occur in several ways: 1) an anatomical edge is present but has no corresponding functional edge (extra edge), 2) a functional edge exists with no corresponding anatomical edge (missing edge), and 3) there is a misregistration error between the two types of edges. Note that extra edges can arise in two ways: either an anatomical edge is erroneously drawn, or the anatomical edge is correct, but there is simply no corresponding functional edge at that location. Also, a missing edge can occur in two ways; either a significant anatomical edge is missed, or a strong functional edge occurs at an unexpected location.

The initial foray into testing this sort of robustness is depicted in the modified edge map of Fig. 3(h). Here there is an extra (diagonal) edge in the lower right corner, and an obvious band of missing edge information in the upper region. In addition, a general blurring of the edge map reflects our uncertainty in registration between the modalities. (For a real SPECT study, this blurring would translate into a misregistration error of about f 3 mm). A discussion of our model of this uncertainty is found in Section 11. The plateau threshold remained the same (14) and the total number of iterations was 409. We now discuss the subjective quality of our results; later we present a quantitative assessment. Our best result using anatomical information, Fig. 3(e), shows good image quality even in regions of low contrast. Detailed spatial structures appear well defined. The effect of a large band of missing edges as well as an extra diagonal line (lower right) is seen in Fig. 3(f). Overall, the image quality in the region corresponding to the band of missing edges degrades slightly with some detail lost in the low-contrast structures. There was no visible degradation due to the extra diagonal line. In addition, there is a slight loss of detail due to the blumng of the anatomical edges. Comparatively speaking, the weak membrane results in Fig. 3(d) are more patchy, especially in regions where the phantom was uniform (e.g. gray matter). Small details, such as the border between the gray and white matter of the brain are not as well preserved in the weak membrane reconstruction. Not surprisingly, both the FBP and EM-ML reconstructions (Figs. 3(b) and (c)) are noisier than the MAP reconstructions. Compared to the best intermodality reconstructions, the small, detailed structures in FBP and EM-ML are not as clearly resolved.

The RMS error relative to the phantom was evaluated for selected ROIs in order to quantitatively assess the efficacy of our algorithm. Figure 4(a) displays RMS error vs. iteration number for a ROI corresponding exactly to the bright, outer region of the phantom. As seen, the Bayesian reconstructions result in improved quantitations in this region; the addition of prior anatomical information results in further improvement relative to the Bayesian reconstruction obtained without the anatomical information (weak membrane). Note also that the RMS error obtained with the modified (with blurred, missing and extra edges) edge map is nearly identical to the result obtained with the perfect edge map. This illustrates a robustness of the algorithm to slight errors in the edge map. Figure 4(b) shows a similar plot for the ROI corresponding to the intermediate (white matter, value equal to 25) region. Once again, the Bayesian reconstructions show considerable improvement over FBP and EM-ML, and the addition of anatomical prior information is clearly beneficial.

We also ran the algorithm on a second phantom shown in Fig. 5(a). This 32 x 32 phantom consists of three regions of values 75, 130 and 150 against a background of 100. Projection data was mathematically generated by calculating the Radon transform using 32 equiangular projections around 180 degrees with 32 detector bins per projection. Independent Poisson noise was added to each detector bin.

Figure 5(b) shows the result obtained using FBP with a ramp filter. Figure 5(c) shows the result obtained using EM-ML after 50 iterations, where the number of iterations was selected to correspond to the minimum RMS error relative to the phantom.

As with the previous phantom, we ran the Bayesian reconstructions with weak membrane and anatomical priors. For the anatomical priors, we used an edge map with missing and extra lines but without blur. Figure 5(f) shows the anatomical edge map used in the intermodality reconstruction. Comparison with the phantom in Fig. 5(a) shows a missing edge (upper right) and false edges constituting an extra region (center). The parameters for the weak membrane reconstruction were X = 0.77 and 1c1 = 17.0 with e ( i , j ) set to zero everywhere. The energy function no longer depends on 1c2 once e ( i , j ) is set to zero. The parameters for the intermodality reconstruction were X = 0.7, 1c1 = 15.0 and K~ = 5.0. The plateau thresholds for both reconstructions were equal to 4.

Figure 5(d) shows the weak membrane reconstruction after 617 iterations. The reconstruction is generally smoother than FBP or EM-ML but note the error in the reconstruction of the boundary of the upper left region. When anatomical information is employed as shown in Fig. 5(e), the error is corrected and the resulting reconstruction is qualitatively superior. Figure 5(e) shows the result after 682 iterations.

As before, in order to quantitatively assess the performance of our algorithm, we plot the RMS error vs iteration for two ROIs. Figure 6(a) displays RMS error vs. iteration number for an ROI corresponding exactly to the bright upper right region of the phantom; Fig. 6(b) shows the RMS error for an ROI corresponding exactly to the background (i.e. the region in the phantom with value 100). As seen, the Bayesian reconstructions result in improved quantitations in these regions; the addition of prior anatomical information results in further improvement relative to the reconstruction obtained without the anatomical information (weak membrane).

V. CONCLUSION We have proposed a Bayesian model that incorporates prior knowledge of correlated anatomical discontinuities into reconstructions of functional images. Initial results, obtained by using two mathematical phantoms with a single noise realization in each case, are encouraging and show that the anatomical information leads to improved reconstructions. Also, the algorithm appears robust to errors such as missing or incorrectly placed anatomical boundaries.

Our approach is distinguished by two features. The mechanism for incorporating anatomical information is expressed as a space varying modulation of the potential that controls the creation of a discontinuity. The second feature involves our justification of the use of a cusp-like potential. The discussions in Section I11 argue for two advantages of the cusp-like potential.

While these initial tests are encouraging, they are limited. As is common in phantom testing of reconstruction algorithms, the source distribution in the phantom is spatially piecewise constant. This feature crudely reflects an assumption that radionuclide is uniformly distributed in certain anatomical regions. However, in the case of Bayesian approaches with priors (such as the weak membrane) that favor such piecewise constant solutions, it may be important to more accurately model underlying source distributions, particularly in the vicinity of boundaries (edges) in the source. If, for example, the underlying source has edges that roll off gradually, the advantage of a Bayesian solution with weak membrane priors may be diminished. An effort in accurate modeling of underlying source distributions is needed. In addition, several outstanding problems remain before the use of anatomical information as priors can be practicable. Validation studies showing the correlation of anatomical structures with function for different types of radiopharmaceutical studies are necessary, of course. Given reliable knowledge of anatomy-function correlation, there still remains the problem of analyzing a given anatomical image to derive only those boundaries that are significant in the sense of likely correlation to function. A prerequisite for this analysis task is a sophisticated segmentation algorithm that can reliably identify different tissue types within the anatomical slice. In addition, accurate 3-D registration is required along with an improved means of modeling residual registration errors into the reconstruction procedure.
In sum, we have explored one possible avenue for incorporation of anatomical information into a reconstruction problem.
